7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:00): I need some help. On my other computer I am unable to boot from CD (it's not a bios issue... it's just a ghost in the machine) and since I don't have floppy disks I had to find a workaround to install Windows XP.

7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:01): Since I have a computer that can boot from CD I took the hard drive from my other computer and put it in the cd bootable computer and installed windows 98 on it since it can be moved from computer to computer with no issues and the windows xp cd can start the install from within windows so it bypassed the need to boot from cd.

7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:02): I clicked on the wrong option apparently because Windows XP installed on my other hard drive (I have two hard drives in the non-cd bootable machine) and so now I have two complete installs of Windows on two different hard drives... 98 is on C drive and XP is on D drive
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:03): I want to get rid of Windows 98 and make what is now D drive into C drive.
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:03): Can someone help me?
a4687444fb35a0a63d65953dd342dfc4 (14:04): Um, if you don't have anything invested in it delete everything and start over. It's not easy to change the letter of a system partition.
a4687444fb35a0a63d65953dd342dfc4 (14:05): Otherwise, just wipe out the 98 disk and put the bootloader and boot sector on the XP disk and live with the fact that it's called D
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:06): how would I put the bootloader and boot sector on the xp disk? Put it in my CD bootable computer, put in the win xp cd and do a fixmbr?

a4687444fb35a0a63d65953dd342dfc4 (14:07): Yeah, make the partition active as well, do fixmbr (probably not necessary as the MBR will be OK as it is) and fixboot, and copy ntldr, ntdetect.com and boot.ini from the 98 disk to the XP one.
a4687444fb35a0a63d65953dd342dfc4 (14:08): And edit boot.ini as necessary.
c01e287596d8d0bf8decfaee9613616a (14:08): Techno: search the knowledge base
c01e287596d8d0bf8decfaee9613616a (14:08): there is an article on changing disk ids
c01e287596d8d0bf8decfaee9613616a (14:08): so you can just change d to c
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:08): you know...
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:08): I've already done a search... it's sorta hard to find an answer from a database when you're in a unique situation.

a4687444fb35a0a63d65953dd342dfc4 (14:09): Perhaps a better approach to doing this anyway would be to do the text-mode section of XP install on the CD-bootable machine and then before it goes into GUI mode transfer the disk into the other machine.
fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:09): you could have done stage 1 install then swapped the disk over

c01e287596d8d0bf8decfaee9613616a (14:09): Techno: its not that unique, ive done it before
c01e287596d8d0bf8decfaee9613616a (14:09): thats how i know the article exists
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:09): Well, disk letter isn't important as I plan on usling LDM to put the two drives together into one big partition

fb4dbbe2a70f6a0a0eaa10dead26c669 (14:10): http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk maybe?

c01e287596d8d0bf8decfaee9613616a (14:13): Techno: why would you want to decrease reliability on a box thats going to be a file server?
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:13): what do you mean?
c01e287596d8d0bf8decfaee9613616a (14:13): spanned arrays are less reliable than single disks
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:14): but they're more convenient

7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:15): let's say I have 15gb of files I need to store and each disk on the file server only has 10gb free... that means that I have to split the files up and then later remember than i did split them up
c01e287596d8d0bf8decfaee9613616a (14:16): personally i consider organising files easier than losing them but each to his own
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:18): well... is there a way for my networked computers (both on win xp) to see two shared folders on the same machine as one folder?
ce8c259e2b7bef2f198e2acccca96efc (14:18): would you say an pplication is "launching", or that it's "starting up"
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:19): I say an application is 'loading'
a4687444fb35a0a63d65953dd342dfc4 (14:19): Riis, as far as I'm concerned they're synonyms.
ce8c259e2b7bef2f198e2acccca96efc (14:20): which is the more "professional" saunding of the three then?
ce8c259e2b7bef2f198e2acccca96efc (14:20): I guess loading is...
ce8c259e2b7bef2f198e2acccca96efc (14:21): damn dvorak
ce8c259e2b7bef2f198e2acccca96efc (14:21): *As and Os
a4687444fb35a0a63d65953dd342dfc4 (14:21): "loading" doesn't imply "executing" though. I'd say launching in a technical publication.
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:22): but you are in fact loading a program when you execute one
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:22): you are loading it into memory which boots it up. It also can imply loading a program into the clipboard for a copy/paste procedure.
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:22): 'loading' is far more versatile and far more common
7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:23): how often in a video game, for example, do you see 'launching...' as opposed to 'loading...'?

7daaa7423e17898ed678e8e1a0653ddb (14:24): in any case... anyone know if there is a way for one computer with a shared folder on two different hard drives can appear to have one folder when a computer on the network checks it?
